data.title: A Work of Artifice by Marge Piercy: Analysis and Summary
data.meta_description: Learn about the theme, style, title, summary, and questions with answers of the poem A Work of Artifice by Marge Piercy. This article also provides a critical appreciation, meanings, figures of speech, and imagery of the poem.
data.text:
Interesting facts about the poet:

Marge Piercy is an American poet, novelist, and social activist who was born on March 31, 1936, in Detroit, Michigan.

She attended the University of Michigan and earned a bachelor’s degree in literature.

Piercy has published over 20 volumes of poetry and more than 15 novels, including the best-selling “Gone to Soldiers,” which is set during World War II.

She is also a political activist who has written and spoken out about issues such as feminism, environmentalism, and social justice.

Piercy was the recipient of the Arthur C. Clarke Award in 1991 for her science fiction novel, “He, She, and It.”

In addition to her writing, Piercy is a practicing Wiccan and has written several books about Wiccan spirituality, including “Woman on the Edge of Time” and “Braided Lives.”

Piercy has been married three times, and her second husband was the poet Robert B. Silvers, who co-founded The New York Review of Books.

She has received numerous awards and honors throughout her career, including the Carolyn Kizer Poetry Prize and the Golden Rose Award from the New England Poetry Club.

Piercy currently resides in Wellfleet, Massachusetts, and continues to write and speak out on issues of social justice.

Figures of speech:

The poem “A Work of Artifice” by Marge Piercy is a small poem about a large subject. It uses a bonsai tree as a metaphor for the ways that society shapes and limits individuals, especially women. Some of the figures of speech in the poem are:

Personification: The poet gives human qualities to the bonsai tree, such as being “cozy, domestic, and weak”. This helps to compare the tree to a human being who has been pruned and controlled by society.

Alliteration: The poet uses words that start with the same sound to create a rhythmic effect:

EG: “whittles back the branches” (line 8).

Irony: The poet uses words that have a different or opposite meaning than what is expected, such as “lucky” (line 13) and “love” (line 16). This creates a contrast between the gardener’s view and the poet’s view of the bonsai tree.

Metaphor: The entire poem is a metaphor that compares the bonsai tree to a woman who is shaped and controlled by societal norms and expectations.

EG: ” the crippled brain”

EG: ” the hair in curlers”

Symbolism: The bonsai tree is a symbol of the ways in which women are constrained and controlled by societal expectations. The “pot” in which the tree is planted can also be seen as a symbol of the restrictive roles and expectations placed upon women.

Imagery: The poem contains vivid imagery, such as the image of the “hair in curlers” and the “hands you love to touch,” which serve to reinforce the themes of confinement and domestication.

Summary:

“A Work of Artifice” by Marge Piercy is a poem that uses the metaphor of a bonsai tree to comment on the societal expectations placed on women. The poem tells the story of a gardener who carefully prunes and shapes a bonsai tree into a beautiful display. Despite the fact that the tree could have grown to be eighty feet tall, the gardener limits its growth to a mere nine inches. The gardener croons to the tree that it is lucky to be small and cozy, domestic and weak, and to have a pot to grow in. The poem’s central theme is the idea that women are constrained and controlled by societal expectations that limit their potential. The bonsai tree is a symbol of women, and the pot in which it is planted represents the restrictive roles and expectations placed upon them. The poem uses personification, hyperbole, irony, symbolism, and imagery to convey its message and comment on the societal pressures that women face.

Impact of societal expectations on women’s growth and potential:

“A Work of Artifice” by Marge Piercy is a poem that explores the impact of societal expectations on women’s growth and potential. Through a close reading of the poem, we can see how the bonsai tree serves as a metaphor for the ways in which women are shaped and constrained by cultural norms and expectations.

The poem begins with the lines, “The bonsai tree / in the attractive pot / could have grown eighty feet tall / on the side of a mountain / till split by lightning.” These lines suggest that the bonsai tree, like women, has the potential for great growth and strength. However, the tree is confined to a small pot, just as women are confined to certain roles and expectations.

The poem goes on to describe the careful pruning of the bonsai tree, as the gardener “clips off” branches. This process of shaping and constraining the tree is similar to the ways in which women are socialized to conform to certain standards of beauty, behavior, and accomplishment. This emphasizes the ways in which women are often reduced to objects of beauty and entertainment, rather than being allowed to grow and thrive in their own right. This can limit their ability to realize their full potential. Like the bonsai tree, women are often kept small and lovely, rather than being allowed to grow and flourish in their own unique ways by the patriarchal society where men are the “gardeners”.

Theme of the poem:

The theme of “A Work of Artifice” literally, by Marge Piercy speaks of the relationship between humans and nature, and the ways in which humans shape and control nature to suit their own needs.

The main idea projected in this poem through the metaphorical use of the bonsai tree is that stunting the growth of women is a clever trick played by the patriarchal society. The control begins early so that what could grow ” eight feet high” is dwarfed to just “nine inches”. The women are so highly conditioned to live within the domestic walls, look attractive and do domestic chores that they start believing that they are ” small, cozy, domestic and weak what the to live protected only “in a pot”. The extreme conditioning cripples the brain and they are almost rendered incapable to think independently and claim freedom.

Through the metaphor of the bonsai tree, the poem explores the impact of societal expectations on women’s growth and potential, and the cost of domestication and constraint. The poem highlights the importance of allowing individuals, including women, to grow and flourish in their own unique ways, rather than confining them to predetermined roles and expectations.

Style of the poem:

The poem “A Work of Artifice” by Marge Piercy is written in free verse, which means that it does not conform to a specific rhyme scheme or metrical pattern. This style of writing allows the poet to use language in a more flexible and expressive way, emphasizing the meaning of the words over their formal structure.

One notable feature of the poem’s style is its use of imagery and metaphor. The bonsai tree serves as a powerful metaphor for the ways in which women are shaped and constrained by cultural norms and expectations. Through the imagery of the tree, the poem vividly conveys the idea of confinement and constraint, as well as the potential for growth and self-expression.

We can say that the poem is allegorical in nature. At the literal level, it is about a bonsai tree but metaphorically talks about women in a patriarchal society. The poem ironically shows that though man resorts to different ways in making his ” thing” an attractive show-piece, he still seeks comfort and admiration from her. He fails to break her in totality.

The poem’s style is also characterized by its directness and simplicity of language. Piercy uses straightforward language and simple syntax to convey her message, making the poem accessible to a wide audience. This simplicity of language is part of what makes the poem so effective in conveying its message, as it allows the reader to focus on the ideas and themes rather than getting bogged down in complex language or symbolism.

Overall, these stylistic choices work together to create a powerful and memorable poem that encourages readers to question the ways in which societal expectations shape our lives and identities.

Irony:

In “A Work of Artifice” by Marge Piercy, the irony lies in the gardener’s attitude towards the bonsai tree. The gardener “whittles back the branches” of the tree and croons “It is your nature to be small and cozy, domestic and weak; how lucky, little tree, to have a pot to grow in.” The irony lies in the fact that the tree’s natural inclination to grow tall and strong has been subverted and controlled by the gardener, who has forced it into a small and weak form that is suitable for display as an ornamental object. (SITUATIONAL IRONY)

Furthermore, the gardener’s admiration of the bonsai tree is also ironic. Although the gardener has limited the tree’s growth and potential, he still finds pleasure and comfort in its beauty. This speaks to the larger theme of the poem, which is the societal expectations placed on women to conform to certain roles and expectations. Like the bonsai tree, women are often constrained and controlled by societal norms, yet are still expected to be beautiful and pleasing to others.

Thus, the irony in “A Work of Artifice” lies in the contradiction between the gardener’s control over the bonsai tree and his admiration for its beauty. The poem highlights the limitations and costs of societal expectations, and encourages readers to question the ways in which we shape and control both nature and human beings to suit our own desires.

Significance of the title of the poem:

The title of the poem “A Work of Artifice” is significant because it highlights the central theme of the poem – the idea that women are often seen as “works of art” that are created and controlled by men and society. The word “artifice” means a clever or cunning trick, which implies that the shaping of the bonsai tree is a deliberate and intentional act, rather than a natural process. This is an important metaphor for the societal pressures and expectations that women face, as they are often shaped and molded into particular roles and behaviors by cultural and societal norms. The title also suggests that the societal expectations placed upon women are artificial, rather than natural, and that women are capable of breaking free from these constraints and living life on their own terms.

Critical appreciation:

“A Work of Artifice” by Marge Piercy is a powerful and poignant poem that uses the metaphor of a bonsai tree to explore the societal pressures and expectations placed upon women. The poem is structured in three stanzas, each with a distinct message that builds upon the central theme of the poem.

First, the poem uses powerful imagery and figurative language to describe the bonsai tree and the gardener’s careful manipulation of it. The bonsai tree is a symbol of women, while the gardener represents societal pressures and expectations. The use of personification, hyperbole, and metaphor helps to convey the idea that women are often seen as objects to be shaped and controlled by men.

Second, the poem explores the limitations that society places on women, and the impact that these limitations have on their growth and potential. The gardener tells the tree that it is “lucky” to be small and domestic, implying that women are expected to be quiet and submissive, rather than powerful and assertive. The poem suggests that women are often held back from reaching their full potential by societal expectations and gender roles.

Finally, the poem ends on a note of hope and empowerment, as the tree is shown to have some agency and power of its own. Despite the gardener’s efforts to control and shape the tree, it is still able to grow and thrive beautifully in its own way.

In conclusion, “A Work of Artifice” is a beautifully crafted poem that uses metaphor and imagery to explore the societal pressures and limitations placed upon women. Through its careful use of language and structure, the poem highlights the struggles that women face in a patriarchal society, while also offering a message of hope and empowerment. It is a powerful and thought-provoking work that continues to resonate with readers today.
